data.message:
Remove ffmpeg XVMC format parsing. Closes #323

Recent versions of ffmpeg lead to compilation errors. This commit
removes XVMC format parsing. It doesn't seem to be relevant these
days, see https://www.phoronix.com/news/FFmpeg-Drops-XvMC

Credit to [James Otting](https://github.com/Otterverse) for the fix
and link.

data.author: Nikolaus Demmel
data.message:
remove Eigen find module and don't force CONFIG mode

The Eigen find module seems to be unused now, b/c find_package(Eigen3
...) forces CONFIG. However, the generated config files don't force
CONFIG for Eigen and thus they do use the find module (see
`cmake/PangolinConfig.cmake.in`). I suggest the most consistent
behaviour would be removing the find module and not forcing
CONFIG. This also allows projects that include Pangolin to customize
the Eigen location by supplying their own find module.

data.author: Nikolaus Demmel
data.message:
fix compiler warning on __STDC_FORMAT_MACROS redef

Without this, if I include 2 libraries that define this macro, I get warnings like

```
warning: '__STDC_FORMAT_MACROS' macro redefined [-Wmacro-redefined]
```

This is on macos 10.15 with AppleClang 11.

See also upstream PR: https://github.com/kazuho/picojson/pull/127

data.author: Nigel Carter
data.message:
Fix mouse press event on some touchscreens on X11

On some touchscreens, mouse press events are recognized as mouse release events.
Fix this by looking at the event type instead of the state to determine if the mouse is pressed.

This seems to be due to something in X11 getting into a bad state

Physical mouse / touch screen in good state:
Press: ev.xbutton.state=0, ev.xbutton.type=4
Release: ev.xbutton.state=256, ev.xbutton.type=5

Touch screen in bad state:
Press: ev.xbutton.state=256, ev.xbutton.type=4
Release: ev.xbutton.state=256, ev.xbutton.type=5

data.author: Maxim Antipin
data.message:
Fixing a couple of compatibility issues

1. Fixing an inconsistent usage of 'new []' and 'delete' operators
in utils/threadedfilebuf.cpp.

This inconsistency results in undefined behavior and, potentially,
memory leaks.

2. Removing the explicit 'mpark' namespace specification in
geometry/geometry_ply.cpp.

The `pangolin/geometry/geometry_ply.h -> pangolin/compat/variant.h`
header sequence is supposed to map `get_if` to eiter `std::get_if`
or `mpark::get_if`, depending on compiler version. This explicit
namespace specification breaks this compatibility behavior.

data.author: Nikolaus Demmel
data.message:
Replace MAC_OS_X_VERSION_10_12 by its value 101200

This check was ineffective on macos versions prior to 10.12, since the
constant is not defined there, which caused build failures due to
undefined symbols. By replacing it with the integral value, the
defines should correctly be skipped on macos < 10.12, while behaviour
should remain unchanged on newer versions.

Fixes #327

Add package.xml for catkin_tools.

With this, you can build Pangolin as part of a catkin workspace
with catkin_tools. Note that with this, Pangolin is still a pure
cmake package, not a catkin package. For a catkinized pangolin,
see https://github.com/uzh-rpg/pangolin_catkin.

determine PNG compression level from quality

This causes an exception when initialising the PNG compression.

data.author: Renzo De Nardi
data.message:
limitation:
Since the plotter limits are set programmatically only in the constructor, one can select the portion of the plot in view only using the mouse. 

desired functionality:
Often instead is useful to select the portion in view programmatically (or more simply define a fix plot size in the contructor and then set the view origin to a desired point), but importantly this should work seamlessly with the mouse scaling.
 
proposed approach:
* decouple plot interval from the plot view by introducing a view origin and expressing the plot interval in relative coordinates.

summary of changes applied:
* introduced a new view origin (variable vo[2]) which defines the x,y point about wich the plotter view is defined.
* int_x and int_y now define the view corners wrt the view origin (as opposed to the absolute origin 0,0). 
* vo needs to be summed to the int_x and int_y when setting the camera: gluOrtho2D(int_x[0]+vo[0], int_x[1]+vo[0], int_y[0]+vo[1], int_y[1]+vo[1]);
* mouse panning and track_front now simply entails modifying vo 
* scaling deals only with int_x and int_y
* SetViewOrigin(x0,y0) allows to set the origin programmatically (this is very useful when one wants to have two synchronized plots on different views)
 
note:
since at initialization vo={0,0}, the plotter should retain its standard behaviour when SetViewOrigin is not called.

Improved lool and efficiency of widgets

Signed-off-by: Steven Lovegrove <stevenlovegrove@gmail.com>

data.author: Steven Lovegrove
data.message:
Integrated Widgets with Named Variables. Updated Example

Each Widget can now be efficiently tied to a variable. A panal can be tied to a 'namespace' to automagically add appropriate widgets to manipulate variables falling in that namespace.

Signed-off-by: Steven Lovegrove <stevenlovegrove@gmail.com>

data.author: Steven Lovegrove
data.message:
Rewritten general vars again, but hopefully for the final time.

Variables support basic float, integral, bool and string types. Other types are automatically serialised to and from std::strings. Where requested type and actual type are identical, a simple reference is used, obtained through double indirect pointer. Where a compatible scalar type is requested, an efficient conversion takes place. Other types are converted via the string type. Custom types should overload standard stream operators.

Signed-off-by: Steven Lovegrove <stevenlovegrove@gmail.com>

data.author: Steven Lovegrove

Build enhancements and Var enhancements

data.author: Steven Lovegrove
data.message:
Handler3D improvement and work on named variables.

Handler3D now supports in plane translation through point grabbing allowing very intuitive scene browsing.

Named variables are typed and stored as the original type. A common interface either reads data directly or performs type conversion through strings as an intermediary. Specialisations could be applied to speed up conversion (between numeric types for instance).

Signed-off-by: Steven Lovegrove <stevenlovegrove@gmail.com>
